Graphical abstract This review summarizes recent advances in the rational design of functional separators for lithium-sulfur batteries, emphasizing critical surface binding and surface energy challenges that are critical for electrochemical performance. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) represent a next-generation energy storage technology, but widespread applications are restricted by the shuttle of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). The rational design of separators has been demonstrated to be one of the most efficient and cost-effective strategies to curb the shuttle effect, and tremendous research progress has been achieved. The efficiency of a separator depends on its interaction with LiPSs, which is governed by the surface energy and binding strength. Despite several review works that have been reported to advance the separators, most of them primarily focus on active material innovation and construction. The most crucial issues of surface binding energy have not been systematically reviewed, limiting the precise design of efficient separators. In this review, fundamentals related to surface energy and binding interactions with LiPSs are comprehensively analyzed and discussed. With surface binding and energy main lines, the advancements in separator engineering strategies are elaborately summarized and discussed. Moreover, techniques for evaluating affinity to LiPSs are thoroughly analyzed to avoid any ambiguities in measurement. Based on the research context, valuable research directions are suggested to construct efficient separators. This work provides guidelines to regulate the surface binding and energy of separators for high-performance LSBs. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Separator Surface binding Surface energy Rational design 1 Introduction The lithium-ion battery (LIB), one of the most successful energy storage devices, has reached its theoretical limit in energy density [1,2]. To meet the growing demand for higher energy density, lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have emerged as a promising alternative. Except for a remarkable theoretical energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1, LSBs also offer key advantages, such as good safety and cost-effectiveness, due to the high natural abundance of sulfur [3]. The high energy density arises from the two-electron redox reaction between lithium (Li) and sulfur (S), supported by the high capacities of the Li anode (3860 mA h g−1) and S cathode (1672 mA h g−1) [4,5]. Nevertheless, the commercialization of LSBs is hindered by several challenges, including the low conductivity of S and and its discharge products, Li dendrite formation, dissolution of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), and sluggish conversion reactions (Fig. 1a ). The poor electrical conductivity of S and its discharge products results in a high overpotential, slowing down electrode kinetics and compromising energy density [6]. The dissolution of LiPSs induces the shuttle effect, causing irreversible loss of active material and leading to a decrease in specific capacity and energy density [7]. Moreover, the dissolved LiPSs may convert to short-chain polysulfides or deposit as a passivation layer on the anode, further reducing Coulombic efficiency and cycle stability [8]. During early charge-discharge cycles, reactions between Li and the electrolyte at the solid-liquid interface form a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer [9]. The generation of Li dendrites results in the repeated breakdown and reformation of the SEI layer, thus exacerbating the failure of LSBs by consuming electrolytes and reducing Coulombic efficiency [10–12]. Additionally, Li dendrites may pierce the separator to contact the cathode directly, posing significant safety hazards [13,14]. Various strategies have been advocated to address these challenges, including S host material design [15,16], LiPSs catalysis additives [17,18], artificial SEI layers [19,20], solid-state electrolytes [21,22], and separators [23–25]. Among these, rationally designed separators are the most promising. Besides preventing short circuits in LSBs, the functional separator can restrict the shuttle of LiPSs and evenly distribute the Li ion flux, thus effectively mitigating the shuttle effect and suppressing Li dendrite growth. Moreover, suitable modification of conventional membranes, typically made of single-layer polypropylene (PP), polyethylene (PE), or three-layer PP/PE/PP composites [26], can also address their weaknesses of large pore sizes, poor electrolyte wettability, inadequate mechanical strength, and low thermal stability (Fig. 1b). Additionally, modified separators, being closely integrated with the sulfur cathode, can act as “secondary electrodes”, facilitating the redox reactions of adsorbed LiPSs, reactivating “dead sulfur,” and improving sulfur utilization efficiency [27–29]. As a result, tremendous research efforts have been directed toward the modification of separators to improve the cycling performance, capacity, and energy density of LSBs. In designing separators, their binding strength to LiPSs, which is referred to as surface binding affinity and reflected by the binding energy (eV), is crucial for mitigating the shuttle effect. The binding strength is determined not only by the physicochemical properties but also by the surface states of the separators. A separator with high surface energy, defined as the excess energy at the surface of a material compared to the bulk [30], is more reactive and hence more likely to adsorb LiPSs. Therefore, regulating the surface energy of the separator could tune the binding energy to LiPSs, thus dramatically improving the electrochemical performance of LSBs. However, a separator with excessively high surface energy usually suffers from instability. While previous studies highlighted the role of separators and their fabrication techniques [26,31–34], there remains a lack of a unified framework linking separator design to key performance metrics of surface affinity and energy. This review examines innovative materials and structural modifications for separators in LSBs, by focusing on surface binding affinity and surface energy issues. By framing these properties as core design principles, we provide a comprehensive overview of current advancements and limitations. Moreover, insightful future research directions are offered based on these principles, aiming to boost the development of efficient separators for the widespread application of LSBs. 2 The surface binding affinity and surface energy Before delving into specific separator designs, we outline the fundamental roles of separators in LSBs. Except for physically separating the S cathode and Li anode to prevent the short circuits, separators can function as “secondary electrodes”, as mentioned earlier. In LSBs, catalytic conversion involves the adsorption of reactants, diffusion to active sites, catalysis at active centers, and desorption of products (Fig. 2a ) [35]. Optimal catalytic performance requires a moderate binding affinity between the electrode (including the “secondary electrode”) and LiPSs [36–38]. However, directly calculating or measuring the binding affinities for all intermediates is challenging. Simplified indicators such as the d/p-band center, coordination number, and bond length are commonly used to estimate binding affinity trends. Notably, for nanoscale systems, finite-size effects may render coordination numbers less accurate, particularly for small nanoparticles (NPs) [39,40]. In principle, the above indicators of d/p-band center, coordination number, and bond length can be linked to the surface energy and “dangling bond” states. As illustrated in Fig. 2b, unsaturated coordinating atoms fail to fully bond with neighboring atoms, resulting in “dangling bond” states [41]. The density of these dangling bonds serves as a descriptor for surface activity and correlates with surface energy ( γ ) through the following relationship [42,43] γ = ∑ α I α d E α 2 S where α , E α , I α d , and S are the bond name, bond energy, equivalent dangling bond number of a bond, and area of a particular crystal facet, respectively. Enhancing the density of dangling bond states can increase the availability of d/p orbital states and elevate the density of states (DOS) near the Fermi level, thereby providing abundant electronic states for charge transfer (Fig. 2b) [41,44]. A higher DOS near the Fermi level facilitates stronger orbital hybridization with the molecular orbitals of LiPSs, reducing electron occupancy in antibonding states and consequently strengthening the chemical binding between LiPSs and the separator material [45]. This robust chemisorption effectively immobilizes soluble LiPSs, mitigates the shuttle effect, and stabilizes the electrochemical interface. In addition, high-density dangling bonds serve as catalytic centers that promote efficient electron injection and extraction, accelerating the multi-electron conversion of long-chain LiPSs (Li2S6/Li2S8) into short-chain species (Li2S2/Li2S) during the sulfur reduction reaction (SRR), and vice versa during the sulfur oxidation reaction (SOR) [46]. Surface energy further plays a synergistic role by tuning the interaction strength between the separator and LiPSs. Catalysts with optimized, moderately high surface energy can enhance the chemisorption of polar LiPSs, providing stable anchoring sites for Li–S intermediates while minimizing weak van der Waals interactions. Moreover, elevated surface energy facilitates the nucleation and uniform growth of Li2S, promoting homogeneous deposition and suppressing localized ion fluxes that can trigger lithium dendrite formation. Consequently, engineering both the dangling bond states and surface energy of separator materials not only enhances the trapping of LiPSs but also generates abundant catalytic sites and favorable electronic structures to accelerate the kinetics of the SRR. Accurate determination of dangling bond states and surface energy is a fundamental prerequisite for rational separator design. Dangling bonds can be characterized using experimental techniques such as electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), or through computational approaches including density functional theory (DFT), molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, and crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis. Similarly, surface energy can be evaluated through both experimental methods, such as contact angle (CA) measurements, atomic force microscopy (AFM), and inverse gas chromatography (IGC); and computational techniques, like DFT and MD simulations. 3 Engineering strategies Building on the above concepts, we now explore various strategies to enhance separators in LSBs, including size/morphology regulation, crystal facet engineering, defect engineering, chemical doping, phase engineering/disordered structures, and hybrid structure/surface functionalization. 3.1 Size engineering The size dependence of materials results from both geometrical and electronic effects. In large crystals, anisotropic surface electronic structures limit selectivity in catalysis [47,48]. This issue can be alleviated by size reduction. More specifically, reducing size, from bulk to NPs and ultimately to single-atom catalysts (SACs), enhances the contribution of corner and edge atoms, thus increasing surface unsaturation and surface energy (more active sites and improved atomic utilization) compared to bulk materials (Fig. 3a ). This improvement can be readily understood by the change in volume-specific surface area (VSSA), which is inversely proportional to the diameter (d) of spherical particles: VSSA = 6/d [49]. Consequently, the size regulation of active materials can modulate the properties of the separator. For instance, the V2C MXene separator shows enhanced performance in SRR catalysis and inhibition of Li dendrite when its size decreases from 1000 to 150 nm (Fig. 3b) [48]. The decrease in particle size leads to a larger specific surface area associated with higher surface energy, thereby enhancing LiPSs adsorption and Li–S redox reaction. Meanwhile, as the V2C spheres decrease in size, the resulting high-density channels and voids can homogenize Li ion flux, suppressing Li dendrite growth. Wang and coworkers also demonstrated the cage-confined MoC nanoclusters (sub-2 nm) to ensure robust chemisorption for LiPSs and, therefore, fast SRR [50]. Yuan et al. obtained thin Mo0.25Nb0.75Se2 nanoflakes via an alloying technique [51]. The small size not only optimizes the adsorption energy but also enhances the wettability, thus ensuring a low electrolyte/sulfur ratio of 2.36 μL mg−1 that further restricts the shuttle of LiPSs for higher electrochemical performance. Feng et al. proposed metallic Co clusters and CoN4 SAC decorated Ketjen Black and ultrathin MXene (Co/CoN4@KB-MX) to modify separators. They showed that Co clusters promote adsorption and catalytic capabilities for long-chain LiPSs, whereas CoN4 sites enhance absorption of short-chain LiPSs and promote the conversion to Li2S. Meanwhile, the Ketjen Black and MXene further physically block and chemically anchor leaking LiPSs. This catalyst creates the adsorption-catalytic interface that accelerates SRR kinetics, thereby achieving a high reversible capacity of 781.59 mA h g−1 and a low-capacity decay rate of 0.047% per cycle at 4 C [52]. As the size of active materials continues to decrease, from bulk particles to nanoclusters and eventually to isolated single atoms, significant changes occur in both surface energy and binding behavior. Compared to nanomaterials and clusters, SACs represent the extreme case of size reduction, offering higher surface energy and more unsaturated coordination environments [54–56]. Xu and coauthors demonstrated the use of Ni single-atom-loaded MoS2 nanosheets to modify the PP membrane (Fig. 3c), achieving excellent cycling stability (0.01% capacity decay per cycle at 2 C) [53]. This configuration also delivered an initial capacity of 6.9 and 5.9 mA h cm−2 after 50 cycles, with a high S loading of 7.5 mg cm−2. Other metal SACs such as Fe [57], Co [58], Cu [59], and Mn [60] have also been explored to modify separators, verifying the great potential of SACs in LSBs. Theoretical understanding of the interaction between various metal SACs to Li-S species can be established through d-p hybridization [45,48]. As illustrated in Fig. 3d, the px / y /z states of S in Li2S are fully occupied by six electrons, filling low-energy σ and π bonding states. The remaining anti-bonding and non-bonding states are determined by the d orbitals of SACs. As the number of 3d electrons increases from Sc to Cu, the d band center lowers away from the Fermi energy level, resulting in more anti-bonding states below the Fermi energy level to be filled. This is the same in the band structure of the corresponding bulk system (Fig. 2b), where a smaller dangling bond state gives more electron population in the anti-bonding state to reduce the chemical affinity [41]. It is anticipated that transition metals with lower atomic numbers are more efficient in d-p hybridization owing to fewer filled anti-bonding states. Nevertheless, the atomic radius of metals should also be considered when evaluating the d-p hybridization, as the large atomic radius of Sc weakens the M–S bond [45]. Despite these progresses, challenges remain in improving the separator for LSBs. • The optimal binding affinity of the catalyst for LSBs is still uncertain. While high binding affinity may help to trap LiPSs, it is not always beneficial to facilitate SRR [37]. • The actual binding affinities of SACs can differ from theoretical predictions, as these catalysts are typically anchored by external coordination that affects their real interactions with the reactants. • The high catalytic activity of SACs is often accompanied by stability issues, which need further attention to ensure long-term SRR. In terms of structural stability and activity of SACs, the coordination configuration should be fully considered, aside from the central metal atoms. Various coordinative atoms (e.g., N [61], O [62], S [63], B [57], and P [64]) have been reported to mount metal SACs. The N atom has high electronegativity (3.04, higher than 2.55 for C) and a similar size to Li+. Therefore, the N coordination configuration is suitable for interacting with the terminal Li atom of LiPSs. Compared to N, the O atom has a higher electronegativity (3.44) and can donate more charge density to the metal center, thus enhancing the stability of SACs and providing stronger interaction with Li+ [65]. Nevertheless, the above descriptions should be refined, as the N and O dopants on carbon host materials are usually achieved in different configurations (e.g., in-plane N doping and out-of-plane O doping). This explains why N-doped configurations are more frequently utilized than O-doped structures. An example here is the classic M-N4 (M: metal) structure, which has been proven highly efficient in improving structural stability and SRR kinetics [66,67]. These M-N4 sites, such as Mn-N4, have been confirmed to weaken the S–S bond in solid Li2S2 to accelerate the SRR [68]. As for the catalytic property, Fang et al. compared the Co-N4 and Co-N2 configurations for LSBs [69]. Density functional theory (DFT) simulations suggest that the reduced N coordination of Co-N2 disrupts the symmetric electron distribution, thereby increasing polarity compared with Co–N4 [69]. Consequently, the Co-N2 with a d-band center of −0.55 eV is 0.3 eV higher than that of Co-N4 (−0.85 eV), hence facilitating chemical interactions with LiPSs and charge transfer (also see Fig. 2b). Similar regulations on the chemical affinity of metal SACs have also been reported elsewhere [63,64,70]. Nevertheless, this improved chemical affinity of SACs for LiPSs also means fewer and weaker bonds to the support, which reduces the electrochemical stability. Notably, an excessive binding affinity to LiPSs may give a “symmetric” SRR pathway with the generation of solid Li2S2 product [37]. The discussions above suggest that reducing the size of active materials in the separator can, in most cases, improve the energy storage performance of LSBs. However, size reduction also increases the instability of the active materials, which must be carefully balanced. In the case of SACs, both the coordination configuration and bonding strength on the support should be considered when evaluating their catalytic properties [71]. It is still challenging to regulate the local environment of SACs at the atomic level, particularly concerning the SRR mechanism. It has been suggested that the binding affinity of catalysts should be optimized to prevent the formation of solid Li2S2 [37], while others argue that an extremely high binding affinity to LiPSs (e.g., in some metal SACs) enhances the dissociation of S–S in Li2S2, accelerating the SRR [72,73]. The underlying reason may lie in the evolution of the rate-determining step in the SRR, which could involve either preventing the “formation” of Li2S2 (“asymmetric” SRR) [37], or preventing the “accumulation” of Li2S2 (S–S dissociation in Li2S2) [72]. Additionally, most reported metal SACs have an atom loading of approximately 0.1–2 wt.%, which should be aggressively increased to further enhance catalytic activity. In this context, more theoretical modeling is needed to optimize the coordination configurations of SACs, followed by the development of improved fabrication techniques and enhanced loading ratios. 3.2 Crystal facet engineering Crystal facets with a high density of low-coordination atoms possess more dangling bond states, which enhance their chemical affinity to LiPSs and affect the SRR (Fig. 4a ). Fabricating these facet-controlled active materials requires suitable regulation of surface energy, as facets with lower surface energy tend to form during crystal growth (Fig. 4a) [74,75]. With this in mind, Gong et al. fabricated MnO with (111) facet exposure to modify a carbon-based separator for LSBs [76]. Theoretical calculations indicated that the (111) facet of MnO has a surface energy (γ) of 4.31 J m−2, higher than that of the (100) and (110) facets (Fig. 4b). Benefiting from this separator, a high capacity (500 mA h g−1) after 500 cycles and a low capacity decay rate of 0.05% per cycle were demonstrated [76]. Similarly, Yu et al. incorporated high surface energy (110)-facet-dominated VO2 into the separator of LSBs (Fig. 4c), achieving an initial capacity of 1472 mA h g−1, and excellent cycling performance (1038 mA h g−1 remained after 300 cycles at 0.1 C) [77]. This improvement is more evident in high-index facets (HIFs) with a higher density of low-coordinated atoms and more dangling bond states than low-index facets (LIFs) [78,79]. Fig. 4d illustrates the use of the SnO2 (332) HIF in the LSB’s separator. Compared to the SnO2 (111) facet, the SnO2 (332) facet contains more unsaturated threefold- and fivefold-coordinated Sn sites that can adsorb LiPSs and reduce the decomposition energy barrier of solid Li2S2 (Fig. 4d). DFT calculations suggest that the SnO2 (332) facet has more anti-bonding states above the Fermi level than the SnO2 (111) facet, leading to a correspondingly stronger chemical affinity toward LiPSs. A challenge in facet engineering is the finely controlled growth of crystals, which requires the “surface energy match theory” to minimize the total energy [41]. This theory, while not expanded upon here, has been applied effectively in the exfoliation of graphene from bulk graphite [84,85]. These HIFs can be stabilized by ions, surfactants, and by the passivation of surface dangling bond states [41]. Fig. 4a illustrates the stabilization of HIFs with surface capping agents (e.g., organic molecules, inorganic salts, and polymers). With this strategy, Geng et al. demonstrated the growth of MIL-96-Al MOF (metal-organic framework) with controlled morphology and facet exposure, including hexagonal platelet crystals (HPC), hexagonal bipyramidal crystals (HBC), and hexagonal prismatic bipyramidal crystals (HPBC) (Fig. 4e) [81]. The stabilization of HIFs can also be achieved through the “pinning effect”, which involves using an “intermediate” to stabilize two phases with significantly different surface energies [86,87]. By incorporating suitable atoms into the HIF, it is possible to balance both stability and activity. Wang et al. demonstrated this technique by alloying Ni and Pt atoms to form (100) facet-exposed surfaces to improve the chemical affinity toward LiPSs for fast SRR kinetics (Fig. 4f) [82]. An extreme example of facet stabilization is high-entropy alloys (HEAs), which offer significantly enhanced mechanical and chemical stability compared to traditional alloys. Thermodynamically, high entropy increases stability through interactions between constituent elements (ΔG = ΔH − TΔS, where ΔG, ΔH, T, and ΔS are the Gibbs free energy change, enthalpy change, temperature, and entropy change, respectively), especially at high temperatures where the TΔS term becomes more significant [88,89]. Kinetically, HEAs also improve structural stability owing to the size mismatch of different elements, which induces lattice distortion and creates large diffusion barriers to prevent phase segregation [88]. Xu et al. demonstrated the high electrochemical activity and stability of CoNiFePdV HEA, with a high surface area (308.86 m2 g−1), even when synthesized at a high temperature (∼1300 K) (Fig. 4g) [83]. Similarly, the CoNiCuMnMo-HEA has shown promise as a separator for LSBs, giving a very low capacity decay rate (0.055% per cycle at 3 C) [90]. In addition to HEAs, other high-entropy materials also reveal great potential to be efficient separators for LSBs. For example, high-entropy sulfides (NiCoCuTiVS x ) exhibit enhanced adsorption and catalytic conversion of LiPSs for greatly improved cycling performance [91]. The high performance is due to the synergistic effect originating from the multiple metal elements. High-entropy hydroxyphosphate, Co0.29Ni0.15Fe0.33Cu0.16Ca3.9(PO4)3(OH), promotes the LiPS adsorption and conversion owing to various cations, thus delivering greatly enhanced cycling performance (a small decay rate of 0.046 % per cycle at 2 C) and a high energy density of 432 Wh kg−1 [92]. Again, the improved performance of high-entropy materials is ascribed to the enhanced binding affinity to LiPSs [91]. The above discussions suggest that facet engineering is a promising strategy for improving the LSBs. Although HIFs enhance the chemical affinity toward LiPSs and improve SRR kinetics through unsaturated coordination atoms and dangling bond states, their high catalytic activity is often accompanied by thermodynamic instability due to facet reconstruction or phase segregation during cycling. To this end, future crystal facet engineering strategies should pay more attention to confining facet restructuring to stabilize the exposed facets, such as by constructing protective layers. Additionally, establishing a quantitative structure-activity relationship between surface energy, adsorption strength, and catalytic activity would offer a rational principle to guide the design of facet-engineered materials. With further development in the fabrication and stabilization techniques, we anticipate more promising applications of these facet-engineered materials in LSBs as separators. 3.3 Defect engineering Introducing defects into the lattice of a material can break its structural symmetry, leading to electronic polarization and charge redistribution. The newly formed dangling bond states near the defect upshift the d/p band center and increase chemical affinity (Fig. 2b) [41,93–97]. Defects exist in various forms, including vacancies, crystal boundaries, structural dislocations, strained systems, and relaxed bonding structures [41]. Among these, relaxed bonding structures are less commonly discussed but are significant in small structures. A typical example is the graphene nanoribbon, where the edge with a relaxed bonding structure is metallic, thus exhibiting enhanced activity [98–100]. In defective structures, both the defect site and neighboring atoms can serve as active sites. The electrocatalytic properties of carbon materials have been extensively investigated in the presence of defects [101–104]. Edge structures, particularly zigzag edges, have much higher chemical affinity to LiPSs compared to that on the basal plane (Fig. 5a ) [105]. Therefore, to enhance the adsorption of LiPSs, porous carbon materials with a large number of edge sites are better suited as separators. For example, etched carbon materials with improved edge ratios and microporous structures have been shown to reduce the energy barrier for SRR [106]. However, the microporous structure is not ideal for Li+ diffusion. To address this, hierarchical porous carbon may offer a better balance between SRR kinetics and Li+ diffusion. Despite the great potential, the high activity of edge sites, particularly zigzag edges, can lead to structural instability as the edges tend to convert to more stable configurations (e.g., pentagons) [95]. Similarly, topological defects (e.g., pentagons, heptagons, Stone-Wales defects, and distorted lattices) create asymmetric structures with more dangling bond states, resulting in improved binding affinity for LiPSs [95,107]. For instance, carbon membranes with rich pentagonal/heptagonal structures (Fig. 5b) have shown excellent cycling stability, with a low capacity decay of 0.05% per cycle after 700 cycles at 1 C [108]. One of the main challenges in this field is the stability of carbon materials, which may require additional attention to enhance electrochemical stability while maintaining high activity for SRR. This issue will be systematically discussed in Section 3.4. In metal compounds, anion vacancies are commonly introduced to improve chemical affinity for LiPSs. This can be attributed to the unsaturated coordination of the metal atom with higher dangling bond states (or the upshift of the d-band center, Fig. 2b). A typical example is the oxygen vacancy in metal oxides, which has been widely explored in SRR [109,110]. Zou et al. reported that In2O3− x NPs with abundant oxygen vacancies exhibit enhanced SRR kinetics, owing to the oxygen vacancies providing both improved chemical affinity and additional channels for Li+ migration [111]. By incorporating the NPs into the separator, a high initial capacity (1540 mA h g−1 at 0.05 C) and low capacity decay (0.058% decay per cycle at 0.2 C) were demonstrated for the corresponding LSBs. These effects are more prominent in 2D transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) with anion vacancies [112–118]. In MoS2, for example, the sulfur vacancies at edges improve binding affinity to LiPSs and promote the SRR (Fig. 5c) [119]. Cho et al. demonstrated that sulfur-deficient MoS2− x enhances the catalytic conversion of LiPSs compared with MoS2, thus presenting superior electrochemical performance [120]. Besides anion vacancies, cation vacancies can also enhance SRR. To elucidate the critical role of cation defects in SRR, Zhao et al. proposed a Ni3FeN model catalyst involving the iron (Fe) defects [121]. Specifically, Fe atoms are located at the corner sites of the cubic pre-mediator Ni3FeN (Fig. 5d). Removal of some Fe atoms through an etching process (Fig. 5d) results in a surface-distorted Ni3Fe1−ΔN. Because of the asymmetric distribution of electron cloud in Fe vacancies, the d-band center is upshifted to the Fermi energy level to narrow the band gap, which improves binding affinity and hence significantly accelerates SRR kinetics. However, accurately synthesizing cation defects remains challenging due to their high formation energies, which often require destructive procedures [125]. Aside from the above cases, lattice dislocations, strained systems, grain boundaries, and relaxed bonding structures can also be generally viewed as defective structures [126,127]. As mentioned earlier, improvements in the separator of LSBs can be attributed to the polarized electronic structure (with more dangling bond states) associated with these defects. Han et al. applied the lattice mismatch descriptor of I Latt to decipher electronic and structural effects on SRR kinetics, where I Latt equals r Li−S/r catal (r Li−S: atomic distance of Li-S in LiPSs; r catal: average distance between cations and anions of the catalysts) [122]. The investigation showed that decreasing the I Latt enhances the chemical affinity to LiPSs in various Ni2+ containing materials (Fig. 5e). Again, as demonstrated in Fig. 2b, the improved binding affinity to LiPSs is ascribed to the upshift of the d-band center, with more dangling bond states (Fig. 5e). The scaling relationship confirms that a small I Latt endows lower activation energy (for the step from Li2S4 to Li2S2 of the SRR) and Li+ diffusion energy (Fig. 5f). A lower barrier for Li+ diffusion is believed to increase the diffusion rate, thus promoting the reaction between lithium and sulfur for fast SRR kinetics [122]. In similar, surface strain can either upshift (tensile strain) or downshift (compressive strain) the d-band center of metal sites (or the p-band in carbon materials), enhancing or weakening the chemical affinity to LiPSs, respectively [128,129]. The relaxed bonding system, similar to tensile lattice strain, increases atomic spacing to expose more dangling bond states for chemical binding with LiPSs. Wang et al. verified these effects by constructing tensile-strained Ti3C2 MXene/carbon nanotube (CNT) composites [123]. The internal stress on the surface induces lattice distortion and prolongs the Ti–Ti bond, thus narrowing the energy band and upshifting the d-band center (Fig. 5g). This configuration improves the binding ability (see Fig. 2b). Besides, the enlarged energy gap between 3d and 2p of the strained sample facilitates non-metal atoms in bonding with others, achieving a higher electronic state at the Fermi level to weaken the S–S bond in LiPSs. Other defects, such as grain boundary (GB), can also improve binding affinity based on similar principles, which will not be further extended here [130–132]. It should be noted that the above trend of upshifting the d-band center is only applicable to late transition metals with more than half-filled d-bands. Early transition metals, with less than half-filled d-bands, exhibit lower adsorption energies upon lattice expansion, contrary to the behavior of late transition metals [133]. Specifically, tensile strain leads to reduced bandwidth. In late transition metals, band narrowing increases the population of the d-band, which upshifts the d-band center to maintain d-band filling. In early transition metals, the d-band downshifts to preserve the d-band filling [133,134]. Despite the improvements in LSBs from defect engineering, excessive defects are undesirable, on the one hand, as they may cause catalyst structure collapse and over-binding to LiPSs. For example, in CoP, chemisorption and electrocatalytic activity improve with increasing concentrations of P vacancies [135]. Nevertheless, excessive P vacancies lead to agglomeration or phase transitions of CoP, significantly compromising the stability of the resultant separator [135]. On the other hand, highly defective materials frequently undergo structural degradation during cycling processes, further deteriorating the electrochemical stability. To unveil the relationship between defect concentration and catalytic activity, Guo et al. identified a volcano relationship, showing that only an optimal defect concentration can balance the adsorption and desorption of LiPSs for efficient SRR (Fig. 5h) [124]. Another crucial issue associated with defect engineering is the stability of materials. As mentioned earlier, more defects often result in more dangling bond states, which are highly active and may need to be passivated to balance stability and activity. In this regard, chemical doping can help sustain electronic polarization while maintaining structural integrity to counteract chemical etching and structural degradation, which is an important topic to be further discussed in the next section. 3.4 Chemical doping The introduction of heteroatoms into the lattice can induce local electron redistribution and dangling bond states near the dopant that alter the chemical affinity toward LiPS. With appropriate dopants, doping can also enhance the electrochemical stability of the active materials. These features make chemical doping a powerful strategy to balance chemical affinity with chemical and structural stability. The following sections will explore non-metal doping (Section 3.4.1), metal doping (Section 3.4.2), and co-doping (Section 3.4.3) of host materials as separators of LSBs. 3.4.1 Non-metal doping Both the electronegativity and atomic radius of dopants affect the host materials significantly [136]. In carbon host materials, an increase in the electronegativity of dopant relative to carbon leads to a greater accumulation of positive charge on neighboring carbon atoms, thereby enhancing the dipole moment that interacts with LiPSs (e.g., for both Li+ and S8 2−) [136,137]. Otherwise, carbon can serve as an active site for adsorbing negatively charged molecules (e.g., S8 2−, Fig. 6a ). For negatively charged dopants, the atomic radius should be small enough to facilitate orbital hybridization and overlap with Li+ in LiPSs (a larger atomic radius can induce geometrical distortion and the introduction of O atoms (Fig. 6a) [124,136]. These effects explain why heteroatoms such as N and O with high electronegativity can serve as electron-rich donors, exhibiting a higher affinity for LiPSs (Fig. 6b) [138,139]. For example, an N-doped carbon modified separator results in a very low capacity decay rate of 0.047% per cycle at 1.0 C of LSBs [140]. Although F is the most electronegative element, the charge at the local binding site is minimal owing to its distinct molecular orbitals. The filled p orbitals of F form a p-π conjugation with carbon, where electron feedback from F to carbon reduces the local charge on F. The combined electron-withdrawing σ effect and electron-releasing p-π effect further reduce the negative charge on F [141]. In contrast, N and O atoms not only participate in the delocalized π system of carbon but also withdraw electrons through σ interactions, which enhances their negative charge. Consequently, F-doped carbon exhibits lower chemical affinity toward LiPSs compared to O- and N-doped carbon (Fig. 6b) [141]. In addition to atomic radius and electronegativity, the presence of a lone pair of electrons in the dopant (which serves as a Lewis base) may also affect the chemical affinity of host materials [141,142]. This is exemplified by pyrrolic-N, which has better chemical affinity than other N-doped configurations owing to its lone pair of electrons [37,61]. By incorporating pyrrolic-N into the carbon-based separator, Yan et al. demonstrated a stable long-cycle performance, giving a reduced energy barrier for the reduction of Li2S4 and Li2S2 [143]. As discussed previously in Section 3.1, the SRR with N-doped carbon materials is complex and cannot be solely explained by improved chemical affinity for LiPSs. Theoretical modeling shows that the high chemical affinity of pyrrolic-N may lead to the formation of solid Li2S2, which is undesirable for the SRR. This can be avoided by reducing the chemical affinity to Li2S4 through the pyridinic-N and graphitic-C configurations [143]. It is important to note that catalysts with much higher chemical affinity (e.g., the binding energy of approximately 6 eV) may enhance the SRR by accelerating the dissociation of the S–S bond in Li2S2. Discrepancies in the chemical affinity of different N-doped configurations in the literature may be due to the improper selection of Li2S x configurations [144,145]. Additionally, N-doped carbon materials often suffer from protonation, which may affect electrochemical stability [146,147]. This issue may not be too severe when N-doped carbon materials are solely used as separators in a nonaqueous environment. Unlike the N dopant, the B atom cannot afford a lone pair of electrons since it only has three valence shell electrons, giving relatively weak binding affinity to LiPSs of B-doped carbon materials (Fig. 6b) [141]. Nevertheless, the B-doped carbon has a particular advantage in electrochemical stability, promoted by the proton-like B atom. The incorporation of electron-deficient boron into the carbon lattice reduces local electron density, thereby suppressing the tendency of the oxidation of the carbon framework and mitigating the risk of radical attacks [148]. During the catalytic conversion of LiPSs, boron-doped carbon demonstrates minimal B-site dissolution, in contrast to the large proportion of C–N bond cleavage observed in N-doped counterparts [149]. Furthermore, the relatively high defect formation energy (∼3.5 eV) for B substitution in the carbon matrix indicates high structural integrity, making atomic rearrangement or detachment less likely during electrochemical cycling [150]. Collectively, the superior stability of boron-doped carbon materials stems from the synergistic effects of strong covalent bonding, electron-deficient characteristics, and exceptional chemical inertness. Furthermore, a coupling can be formed between the motion of the proton and the distribution of electrons among different dopants. This coupling effect improves the electrochemical performance by affecting the electronic structure, proton migration, and interaction energy [148–152]. Consequently, studies have concentrated on co-doping with B and N/O to balance the chemical activity and stability [152,153]. As for the P and S dopants in carbon materials, their lower electronegativity and larger atomic radius, compared to O and N, result in weaker electronic interactions and longer bond lengths. This leads to reduced electronic regulation and potential structural instability [145]. Therefore, sole P and S doping do not provide satisfactory interactions with LiPSs and are often used in co-doping strategies [154]. Hence, the P and S doping will not be discussed further. Non-metal doping (e.g., N, B, O, F, P, S) significantly modulates the electronic structure and surface chemistry of carbon materials, thereby influencing their affinity toward LiPSs and catalytic activity. Specifically, the electronegativity of dopants governs the charge distribution to affect LiPSs adsorption through electron polarization (as exemplified by N and O doping). However, a critical trade-off exists between stability and activity. For example, N doping offers higher activity but suffers from protonation susceptibility and C–N bond cleavage for inferior stability. In contrast, while B doping exhibits superior electrochemical stability due to its electron-deficient nature and strong B–C covalent bonding, B-doped carbon demonstrates relatively weak binding energy to LiPSs for low activity. To reconcile these competing factors, co-doping strategies (e.g., B/N) may optimize electronic structure and strengthen active sites, thereby synergistically enhancing activity and stability. 3.4.2 Metal doping Metal doping significantly influences the Fermi level. In n-type metal doping, where the dopant element has more valence electrons than the host material, the surface dangling bonds readily accept electrons. This results in a relatively positive charge within the host material, forming an electric field directed toward the surface (upward bending of the surface energy band) and leading to an upshift of the Fermi energy level toward the conduction band (CB) [159]. By contrast, in p-type metal doping, where the dopant has fewer valence electrons than the host material, incomplete covalent bonding creates holes. These holes tend to attract electrons from the surface, resulting in a positively charged surface and a negatively charged interior. This situation creates an electric field from the surface to the interior (downward bending of the surface energy band), which downshifts the Fermi energy level toward the valence band (VB) [159]. The type of dopant directly impacts the electronic structure and surface chemical affinity toward LiPSs. Liu et al. compared the p-type V-doped MoS2 (V-MoS2) and n-type Mn-doped MoS2 (Mn-MoS2) as separators for LSBs [155]. The p-type V-MoS2 catalyst exhibited more pronounced catalytic activity, owing to the significant upshift of the d-band center toward the Fermi level and the optimized electronic structure induced by duplex metal coupling (Fig. 6c). Consequently, the LSBs with the V-MoS2 modified separator delivered excellent long-term cyclic stability (with a small decay rate of 0.013% per cycle at 5 C over 5000 cycles). Despite the higher chemical affinity of p-type doping, it does not always outperform n-type doping in terms of long-term cycling stability [155]. Specifically, the presence of holes in p-type doping may lead to the formation of unstable intermediate states, which negatively affect the stability of LSBs under prolonged voltage conditions. In cyclic tests at 1 C, the LSBs with the Mn-MoS2 modified separator showed better capacity retention (capacity decay rate: 0.053% per cycle) compared to the V-MoS2 modified separator (capacity decay rate: 0.069% per cycle). The above regulations can also be understood from a different perspective. As shown in Fig. 6d, the original px / y /z states of sulfur are already occupied by six electrons, filling the low-energy σ and π bonding states. With an increasing number of 3d electrons in the dopant, from Mn to Cu, more anti-bonding states shift below the Fermi level and become filled, leading to weaker interactions with LiPSs [156]. Shen et al. demonstrated the substitutional doping of the ZnS lattice with 3d metal dopants (Mn2+, Fe2+, Co2+, Ni2+, or Cu2+) to regulate chemical affinity. Notably, the lattice strain induced by these metal dopants also contributed to the shift of the d-band center [156]. Fig. 6e compares the binding energy of Li2S2 and Li2S4 on M0.125Zn0.875S (M: metal dopant). Owing to the maximum elevation of the d-band center, Mn-doped ZnS showed the highest chemical affinity to Li2S2 and Li2S4. On the surface of ZnS doped with metal atoms from Cu to Mn, the projected and integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (pCOHP and iCOHP) of S–S bonds revealed more anti-bonding states away from the Fermi level, thus weakening the S–S bond. Interestingly, Mn0.125Zn0.875S caused a significant electron redistribution, resulting in a near-zero iCOOP for the S–S bond, indicating the almost destruction of the S–S bond (note: the smaller the iCOOP value, the weaker the orbital overlap and chemical bonding). This suggests that Mn0.125Zn0.875S is highly active and can directly dissociate the S–S bonds without the need for electrochemical forces. However, excessive binding between Mn and S could passivate the active site, which explains the volcano trend in the catalytic activity of ZnS doped with metals from Cu to Mn (Fig. 6e). As a result, the Co0.125Zn0.875S with a moderate d-band center exhibits the highest catalytic activity for SRR [156]. In metal doping, the ionic radius of the dopant also affects the electronic structure [157,160,161]. Wang et al. proposed a general electron affinity/ionic radius (E A/ r; E A: electron affinity; r: ionic radius of metal dopants) rule as a criterion to select metal dopants for WSe2 [157]. Among various metal dopants (V, Co, Mo, Zn, Ni, and Cu), a low E A/ r ratio significantly accelerates the SRR. These metal dopants in WSe2 transfer different amounts of electrons into the Se-M (M: metal dopant) bonds, following the order: V (1.194 e) > Co (0.839 e) > Mo (0.640 e) > Zn (0.359 e) > Ni (0.348 e) > Cu (0.335 e). The E A of these metal atoms reveals an inverse trend. The low E A of V leads to a loss of electrons at the metal center, thus increasing the electron density of neighboring Se atoms to improve the binding ability to LiPSs (Fig. 6f). Such behavior accelerates the breakage and dissociation of LiPSs and lowers the energy barrier for Li2S nucleation and decomposition, ultimately promoting fast SRR kinetics (Fig. 6g). Moreover, the larger ionic radius of dopants can induce more Se vacancies and lattice defects, providing abundant dangling bonds to further enhance the affinity for LiPSs [157]. 3.4.3 Co-doping Co-doping with non-metallic dopants characterized by high electronegativity (e.g., N or O) and those with a large atomic radius (e.g., S or P) improves the overall effectiveness of doping strategies [162,163]. In addition, dopants with larger atomic radii induce greater lattice distortions, thus facilitating higher doping levels of highly electronegative elements [164]. The synergistic interaction between these dopants further enhances the affinity for LiPSs and catalytic activity. For example, the S in the N, S co-doped carbon (NSMPC) promotes the transformation of graphitic-N into pyrrolic- and pyridinic-N. The S dopant increases the pyridinic-N content from 38.7% to 40.0% and pyrrolic-N from 38.9% to 42.2%, while graphitic-N decreases from 12.9% to 9.5% [165]. These pyridinic and pyrrolic-N species, alongside thionic S, coexist at carbon edges and vacancies, sharply increasing the number of active doping sites [164,166]. As a result, NSMPC showed 148% and 27% improvements in LiPSs adsorption capacity compared to pure and N-doped carbon materials, respectively. When NSMPC is employed as the separator, the LSBs deliver excellent long-term cycling performance with a very low capacity decay rate of 0.041% per cycle at 0.5 C [165]. Liu et al. further demonstrated the improved SRR kinetics with N, S co-doped holey graphene frameworks (N,S-HGF) (Fig. 6h) [158]. Their study revealed that Li2S6 is not directly produced by the electrochemical reduction of Li2S8 but forms via a disproportionation reaction (Li2S8 + Li2S4 → 2Li2S6) after part of Li2S8 has been electrochemically converted into Li2S4. The N,S-HGF converts Li2S6 to Li2S4 at 2.27 V, higher than 2.19 V for the undoped HGF. At 1.8 V, the remaining Li2S6 was only 3% for N,S-HGF, markedly lower than 20% in HGF, indicating accelerated LiPSs conversion by N and S dopants. This synergy mitigates the shuttling effect by promoting the rapid depletion of high-order LiPSs at higher potentials. By combining metal and non-metal doping, interactions with the sulfur and lithium ends of LiPSs can both be improved [167]. Metal dopants introduce impurity energy levels within the CB and VB, acting as donor or acceptor states to regulate electron migration and conductivity [168,169]. Jiang et al. incorporated the P and Mo co-doped MnO2 (P,Mo-MnO2) into the separator of the LSBs, which showed a high reversible capacity of 927 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C [169]. The P dopant enhances electron donation to increase the charge density around MnO2’s oxygen atoms [170]. Simultaneously, Mo substitutes for Mn in the lattice, creating abundant dangling bonds for LiPSs adsorption. This substitution introduces ionized donor states near the Fermi level, lowering the energy barrier for electron excitation to the CB, thus promoting both electronic structure optimization and higher carrier concentration to improve SRR kinetics [171]. It should be noted that doping of different heteroatoms (e.g., N, S, B, P) may exhibit competitive or interfering effects. For instance, nitrogen doping primarily enhances polysulfide adsorption, whereas sulfur/phosphorus doping predominantly improves catalytic activity. However, mixed doping configurations may compromise the individual advantageous properties of these dopants. Furthermore, while high doping concentrations can enhance adsorption capacity, they may simultaneously disrupt the crystallographic integrity of the host material and impair Li+ transport kinetics. Consequently, future efforts in co-doping strategies should focus on: (i) rational selection of dopants and (ii) systematic optimization of doping concentrations to achieve balanced performance metrics. While co-doping of metal atoms can also exploit synergistic effects to modulate electronic and band structures of host materials, its enhancement mechanisms resemble those of single-metal doping (see Section 3.4.2). Therefore, co-doping of metal dopants will not be discussed in this section. 3.5 Phase engineering and disordered system Phase modulation and the construction of disordered systems can tune electronic properties and surface configurations, enabling precise control over coordination numbers, morphology, and surface arrangements. This strategy leverages increased electronic states near the Fermi level (Fig. 2b) [115], which have been effectively applied to LSBs [172,173]. In 2D TMCs, materials can exist in various phases, such as hexagonal 1H/2H, octahedral 1T, and rhombohedral 3R phases [95]. Among these, the 3R phase has received less attention due to its weak interlayer interactions and poor thermodynamic stability. Exfoliation of the 2H phase into 1H monolayers improves material utilization in electrochemical processes. However, the 1H/2H phases are inherently inert, hindering efficient adsorption of LiPSs. These phases can be transformed into the more active 1T phase. The distinction between the 1H/2H and 1T phases of TMCs is illustrated in Fig. 7a . For group-VI TMCs, the Fermi level of the 1H/2H phase lies within the energy gap between the d z 2 and d x 2 - y 2 , x y orbitals, giving rise to a semiconducting nature. In contrast, the 1T phase exhibits a Fermi level within the partially occupied d-states (dy z, x z, xy ), resulting in metallic behavior. Consequently, the transition from the 1H/2H to the 1T phase enables the TMCs to be more promising for electrochemical processes [95,115,174]. The 1T phase can further transform into the 1T' and 1T'' phases under structural distortions, which improves dangling bond states and surface energy [175–177]. These phases exhibit higher activity (see Section 3.3) for LiPSs adsorption and electrocatalytic conversion. Fig. 7b illustrates the lithiation process that converts 2H-MoSe2 into 1T'-MoSe2. In 2H-MoSe2, only the edge structures are active for LiPS adsorption. In contrast, both the edge and basal plane of 1T'-MoSe2 are active, thus doubling the adsorption energy of Li2S4 compared to 2H-MoSe2. The 1T'-MoSe2 also exhibits superior adsorption of Li2S n (where n ≥ 4) compared to that in the dimethyl ether (DME) electrolyte, effectively mitigating the shuttle effect and enhancing SRR efficiency. Additionally, the improved metallicity benefits Li+ diffusion and electron transfer, thereby improving electrode kinetics. Similar concepts of enhanced metallicity through phase modulation (or improved dangling bond states near the Fermi level) have been demonstrated in MXenes, metal oxides, and metal carbides for improving LSBs [178,179]. Unlike phase-engineered structures, fully disordered (amorphous) systems lack long-range periodic lattice structures [180], resulting in weak atomic bonds, abundant surface defects, and randomly oriented dangling bonds [180–182]. Amorphization complicates the band structure, broadening d-orbital electron distribution and enabling more electrons to reach higher energy levels [183,184], thus enhancing activity beyond that of phase-ordered materials [41]. Li et al. demonstrated the use of amorphous CoO (a-CoO) in LSBs [185]. As shown in Fig. 7c, amorphization alters the coordination and symmetry around Co atoms, redistributing the d-orbitals. In crystalline CoO (c-CoO), the high-energy d-orbitals are d z 2 and d x 2 - y 2 , whereas higher energy orbitals for a-CoO are dxy and d x 2 - y 2 . This electronic redistribution facilitates electron transfer and enhances chemical affinity for LiPSs. Upon Li2S4 adsorption, the d-orbitals of a-CoO split into t2g (dxy , dx z, dy z) and e x ( d z 2 , d x 2 - y 2 ) orbitals, promoting greater electron loss and more effective reactions with LiPSs compared to c-CoO [185]. Similarly, amorphous MIL-88B has been reported by Zhang et al. for modifying the separator of LSBs, demonstrating exceptional capacity retention of 740 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C [186]. While the surface of amorphous structures is highly active, it is inherently unstable. The direct utilization of fully amorphous materials in electrochemical processes is not recommended. To improve their stability in LSBs, amorphous materials should be passivated or stabilized through structural reconstruction [41]. Metastable 1T TMCs with abundant dangling bonds face similar challenges, though they have shown stability in some electrochemical processes. Stabilization of these materials can be achieved by “reducing dangling bonds” and applying the “surface energy matching theory” [41]. Reducing dangling bonds through surface passivation improves stability, but may decrease surface activity. Alternatively, ultrathin heterostructures with minimal interlayer energy can enhance the stability of metastable layers [41]. Such structures leverage the synergistic effects of abundant dangling bond states and enhanced stability during electrochemical processes [187]. Fig. 7d illustrates a 1T-2H MoSe2 heterophase that combines the structural stability of the 2H phase with the high chemical activity of the 1T phase. This heterophase, when incorporated into the separator of LSB, demonstrates excellent rate capability (747.2 mA h g−1 at 3 C) and long cycle life (0.079% capacity decay per cycle over 500 cycles) [188]. Similarly, heterostructures combining crystalline and amorphous phases can improve the stability of amorphous materials [189,190]. For example, in a crystalline-amorphous MoO3 heterostructure, the amorphous phase promotes robust LiPSs adsorption, while the crystalline phase lowers the energy barrier for Li+ diffusion and Li2S formation, jointly facilitating SRR (Fig. 7e) [191]. Although phase engineering and disordered systems can enhance LiPSs adsorption and catalysis, it is crucial to recognize that many highly active materials are thermodynamically unstable [194]. Therefore, balancing stability and activity in metastable materials is essential [195]. In terms of material design, the construction of multiphase interfaces or the formation of lattice-matched interfaces can effectively enhance interfacial stability. From the viewpoint of surface modification, the introduction of coordination effects can stabilize the metastable phase while maintaining activity [196]. Alternatively, constructing a carbon coating with precisely controlled thickness can maintain structural stability and expose adequate active sites to ensure activity at the same time. Moreover, challenges in the qualitative investigation of structure-property-performance relationships remain, potentially limiting further applications. 3.6 Hybrid structure and surface functionalization In hybrid structures and surface functionalized materials, the chemical affinity for LiPSs can also be regulated through effects such as coordination and interfacial interaction [198–211]. By combining a high-polarity component with a high electrical conductivity one, the polarity component adsorbs LiPSs while the conductive component accelerates their conversion, thus collectively enhancing SRR [212]. In the MoS2-MoN heterostructure (Fig. 8a ), for instance, the polar MoS2 can trap LiPSs for efficient adsorption and promote fast Li+ diffusion at low energy barriers owing to the layered structure [197]. MoN, with its high electrical conductivity, accelerates the conversion of Li2S x (x > 2) to Li2S for enhanced electrode kinetics. In MoO2-Mo2N hybrid materials, MoO2 anchors LiPSs through its strong binding ability, while the high conductivity of γ-Mo2N accelerates LiPSs conversion (Fig. 8b) [198]. Therefore, LSBs employing MoO2-Mo2N separator deliver greatly enhanced electrochemical performance. Yang et al. also proposed MXene@COF hybrid materials as separators for LSBs, demonstrating a low capacity decay rate of 0.048% per cycle at 1 C [202]. In this case, the high surface area and tunable pore structure of COFs facilitate LiPSs adsorption and regulate Li+ flux to suppress Li dendrite growth, while the high electrical conductivity and abundant surface functional groups of MXene enhance LiPSs conversion. The MXene/CuCo2O4 hybrid exhibits enhanced adsorption and catalytic conversion of LiPSs and, therefore, protects the lithium anode from dendrite growth, ensuring cycling performance and a high energy density of 417 Wh kg−1 of the pouch cell [213]. In hybrid separators, incorporating polymers or inorganic materials with high elastic modulus can enhance the mechanical strength and stability. This enhancement is demonstrated by the hybrid structure of BN nanosheets and cellulose nanofibers (BNNs@CNFs), where the high elastic modulus and thermal conductivity of BNNs improve heat distribution and suppress dendrite growth [203]. The BNNs@CNFs separator maintains its structure at 150°C for 30 min, while the commercial polyolefin separator deforms significantly. The high thermal conductivity and elastic modulus of BNNs prevent localized overheating and dendrite penetration, promoting uniform Li dissolution and deposition. Besides, the interfaces within hybrid structures can also enhance electron transfer by introducing interfacial states, energy band alignment, electric fields, and carrier concentration differences [204,214]. For example, Yang et al. reported that the MoO2-Mo2N heterostructure improves charge transport between MoO2 and Mo2N owing to the introduction of interfacial states (Fig. 8b), thus resulting in excellent cycling stability (capacity decay of 0.028% per cycle at 1 C) [198]. Hybrid structures can also create an electronic polarization in the interlayer, generating a built-in electric field (BIEF) at the interface [199,204,205,215–217]. The BIEF accelerates Li+ transport, enhances electron transfer, and restricts the diffusion of S n 2−, thus suppressing the shuttle of LiPSs. It also directs the migration of S n 2− to catalytic sites, facilitating a continuous adsorption-migration-conversion process. For instance, SnS2-MXene Mott-Schottky heterojunctions enhance electron transfer through interfacial BIEF [199]. The work function of MXene (4.080 eV) is lower than that of SnS2 (6.606 eV), driving electron transfer from MXene to SnS2, which enhances SnS2's binding affinity for LiPSs. In this system, Ti atoms in MXene lose electrons, while S atoms in SnS2 gain electrons. Upon contact, electrons flow from Ti to S until thermodynamic equilibrium is achieved (the Mott-Schottky effect) (Fig. 8c). The heterointerface accelerates Li+/electron transfer, significantly lowering the Li2S nucleation/decomposition barrier and promoting bidirectional sulfur conversion. Additionally, the p-n heterojunction also generates a BIEF to enhance the conversion of LiPSs, as reported frequently in the literature [205,215]. Owing to the difference in work function of the respective phases, it is rational that hybrid structures generate BIEF to promote the adsorption and conversion of S n 2+ [218,219]. Recently, Yang et al. reported that asymmetric bismuth oxycarbonate, with (Bi2O2)2+ and (CO3)2− atomic layers distributed alternately, also exhibits a strong internal electric field [220]. In this unique structure, the electric field facilitates the adsorption of polysulfides, while the Bi metal center efficiently catalyzes the redox reactions of sulfur species, thus resulting in greatly enhanced electrochemical performance. Considering the simplified synthesis procedures compared with hybrid structures, asymmetric materials are more promising for constructing efficient separators for LSBs. Beyond constructing hybrid structures, surface functionalization can also modulate surface energy and promote interfacial synergy. Hydroxyl (–OH), sulfonic acid (–SO3H), carboxyl (–COOH), and amino (–NH2) groups are widely used to functionalize separators in LSBs, exploiting effects such as hydrogen bonding, coordination, electrostatic shielding, and spatial hindrance [200,201,206–210]. Kong et al. introduced sulfonic acid-functionalized graphdiynes as separators for LSBs, reaching a high reversible capacity of 1084.2 mA h g−1 and good electrochemical stability of the LSBs (a low attenuation rate of 0.053% per cycle for 1000 cycles at 2 C) [206]. The hydrophilic –SO3H groups increase surface energy, exceeding that of the electrolyte. According to the surface energy matching theory, high-energy surfaces promote better wetting by the lower-energy electrolyte, thus improving wettability and enhancing ionic conductivity via the –SO3H functionalization. The strong polarity and spatial hindrance of sulfonic acid groups effectively inhibit the shuttle effect. Similar improvements have also been demonstrated with the functionalization of polar functional groups on active materials [200,207–209,221]. Fig. 8d illustrates the example in which carboxyl-functionalized graphene oxide (GO) membranes serve as ion-hopping sites for Li+ while blocking S n 2− through electrostatic repulsion and steric exclusion [200]. More similar regulations can be found on the ion-selective separators with anionic functional groups [201,210]. A cationic selective Nafion membrane with -SO3H groups allows Li+ ion hopping but rejects S n 2− transport through electrostatic interactions (Fig. 8e). The introduction of the Nafion membrane significantly suppresses the polysulfide shuttle between the cathode and anode [201,210]. Li et al. introduced polydopamine (PDA) and GO to construct an ion-selective separator [222]. The sub-1-nm channels of stacked GO enable selective Li+ migration, while oxygen-containing groups (–COOH and –OH) on PDA prevent S n 2− shuttling via electrostatic interactions. The size-selective and charge-selective effects of the membranes enable the accelerated SRR kinetics. Moreover, the strong covalent bonding between PDA and GO nanosheets stabilizes channel sizes, ensuring excellent stability. The resultant flexible Li-S pouch cell shows stable performance over 400 cycles and a high practical energy density of 378 Wh kg−1. Li et al. grafted phosphate groups onto the backbone of cellulose to construct separators with ion-sieving barriers [223]. The phosphate groups impart a high electronegativity to repel S n 2− form penetrating but facilitate Li+ transfer through the separator, resulting in greatly enhanced durability with a low fading rate of 0.013% per cycle over 1000 cycles at 1 C. In terms of surface functionalization, the solvents and additives in the electrolyte may affect the surface structure of catalysts and induce side reactions. For example, in the 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) solvent, disulfide electrocatalysts (e.g., MoS2, FeS2, CoS2, NiS2, and WS2) can trigger the ring-opening cationic polymerization of DOL during cycling, producing a gel layer that covers the electrocatalysts to deactivate the active sites. To this end, Zhang and coauthors introduced triethylamine, a Lewis base, as a competitive inhibitor to suppress the surface gelation [224]. In the presence of triethylamine additive, it competes with DOL for the adsorption on the Lewis acid sites of the disulfides to prevent the gelation of DOL. The resultant LSBs reveal prolonged cycling lifespan, improved rate responses, and 4 times enhancement in discharge capacities. The LiPSs coexist with the solvents and additives in various solvation structures [225]. Therefore, solvents and additives can compete with LiPSs for adsorption on the active sites, ultimately affecting the electrochemical performance. Zhang and coworkers showed that, with the same initial Li2S6 concentration, graphene shows decreased equilibrium adsorption capacity and adsorption rate constant in the presence of LiTFSI for competitive adsorption [226]. Lv and coauthors introduced a competitive adsorption factor to quantify the competitive adsorption between sulfur species and solvent, by measuring the double-layer capacitances before and after the addition of sulfur species into the solvent [227]. They demonstrated that p-d hybridization strengths of Co and Zn with sulfur species and electrolyte solvents could be controlled by changing the Co/Zn ratio. The Co-Zn alloy with a moderate competitive adsorption factor lowers the activation energy for the conversion of LiPSs to Li2S, giving a platform capacity proportion that is 96% of the theoretical value and has a greatly improved anti-passivation ability. Therefore, hybridization and surface functionalization are effective strategies to engineer separators. These strategies affect the electronic structure at the surface or interface to improve surface energy, thus mitigating shuttle effects [228]. However, extremely high surface energy may lead to “over-adsorption” of electrolyte molecules, resulting in uneven electrolyte distribution and compromising battery stability. Additionally, owing to the distinct physicochemical properties of the respective phases, interface stability and electrolyte compatibility must be considered in hybrid materials. 3.7 Comparison and combination of engineering strategies Among all the strategies discussed, defect engineering and chemical doping have garnered the most research attention, accounting for approximately 25% and 20% of studies (Fig. 9 ), respectively. This interest stems from their effectiveness in generating chemically active sites and tuning electronic structures. However, both approaches face significant challenges, such as difficulties in precisely controlling defect concentrations and dopant distributions, as well as risks of inducing side reactions or compromising structural integrity. Other strategies, including size engineering, facet engineering, and phase control, also offer valuable means to tailor surface properties but are often limited by complex synthesis procedures, stability concerns, or insufficient mechanistic understanding. A comprehensive evaluation of these strategies not only highlights current research hotspots but also reveals underexplored opportunities, particularly in hybrid structures and multi-strategy combinations that integrate complementary functionalities. Such insights are vital for the rational design of high-performance separator materials in future LSB systems. Beyond the application of individual strategies, recent studies have demonstrated that combining multiple engineering approaches offers a more effective route to boost LSB performance. For instance, Huang et al. integrated chemical doping and hybrid structure design by constructing B-doped WS2 nanosheet arrays on MXene (B-WS2@MXene) as a separator modifier [229]. B doping improves electronic conductivity, polysulfide confinement, and catalytic activity, while the vertically aligned nanosheet arrays enhance mass transport and active site exposure. This dual-functional architecture effectively suppresses the polysulfide shuttle and accelerates sulfur redox reactions, delivering a pouch cell with a high capacity of 204 mA h g−1 and a volumetric energy density of 400 Wh L−1 [229]. Similarly, the combination of defect engineering and chemical doping, Se vacancy and N doping, on MoSe2 electrocatalysts has been employed to regulate bidirectional Li2S redox reactions [230]. The resulting system exhibits a remarkably low capacity decay of 0.04% per cycle over 1000 cycles at 2.0 C and achieves a high areal capacity of 7.3 mA h cm−2. More multiple engineering approaches can be found in the synergistic integration of phase engineering and heteroatom doping, where hexagonal Mo2C is converted into cubic B-doped Mo2C (c-B-Mo2C), featuring electron-deficient B sites. This transformation significantly enhances substrate surface properties and improves sulfur redox kinetics. As a result, pouch cells based on c-B-Mo2C demonstrate high energy density (502.1 Wh kg−1, 6.67 Ah, E/S = 2.4 μL mg−1) and maintain 372 Wh kg−1 after 100 cycles in a 2 Ah configuration, indicating strong practical potential [231]. The integration of chemical doping, defect engineering, and crystal facet modulation has also proven effective. For example, ultrafine truncated octahedral TiO2 nanocrystals with exposed (101) facets, P doping, and O vacancies (P-Ov-TiO2) demonstrate enhanced electron transport and Ti-S interactions, which strengthen LiPS adsorption. When used as a separator modifier, P-Ov-TiO2 enables LSBs to achieve a high specific capacity of 895 mA h g−1 at 5 C and a low capacity decay rate of only 0.14% over 200 cycles [232]. Moreover, combining size effects with facet engineering can further amplify performance. Hexagonal plate-like crystals (HPCs) with highly exposed (101) facets exhibit strong polysulfide adsorption and facilitate rapid Li+/electron transport owing to their reduced dimensions. The resulting HPC-S electrode delivers an initial reversible capacity of 1322.7 mA h g−1 and maintains 246.3 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 C, highlighting the critical importance of particle size and crystal orientation in achieving stable long-term cycling [81]. In summary, these examples demonstrate that the synergistic integration of chemical doping, defect engineering, crystal facet modulation, phase regulation, and size control enables precise tailoring of surface chemistry, electronic structure, and ion transport pathways. This multi-strategy engineering framework substantially enhances catalytic activity, cycling stability, and energy density, offering a promising and practical roadmap toward the commercialization of advanced LSB technologies.
