This compilation offers valuable guidance for future material design and industrial translation of high-performance separators in LSB systems. 4 The evaluation of chemical affinity The above discussions highlight the crucial role of the chemical affinity of the separator in curbing LiPSs diffusion toward more promising LSBs. To ensure efficient capture of LiPSs for catalytic conversions, the chemical affinity of the catalyst to LiPSs should be higher than that of the electrolyte (e.g., >0.87 eV for DOL and DME electrolytes) [258]. Otherwise, the electrolyte may strongly compete with LiPSs for adsorption on the catalyst, seriously deteriorating electrochemical performance [226,227,259,260]. As introduced previously in Section 3.1, a high binding strength may facilitate the dissociation of the S–S bond to prevent the accumulation of solid Li2S2 on the catalyst surface [72,73]. Nevertheless, high binding affinity (with the adsorption strength toward the geometry optimized Li2S4 as the standard) is not always beneficial to the SRR, as a suitably weaker binding affinity would provide an asymmetric SRR pathway to avoid the formation of solid Li2S4 intermediate [37,143]. Additionally, a high affinity of the catalyst surface can result in excessive adsorption of the electrolyte, adversely affecting electrolyte distribution and ion transport. This uneven distribution may increase internal resistance, reduce battery efficiency, and destabilize the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film, compromising the safety and stability of LSBs [261]. Understanding the above paradoxical phenomenon should be based on proper evaluation of chemical affinities to LiPSs, which is also fundamental for guiding the design of efficient separators for high-performance LSBs. Therefore, this section will introduce typical protocols to evaluate the chemical affinity of materials to LiPSs, involving experimental methods and theoretical calculations (Fig. 10a ). 4.1 Electrochemical measurement Excessive adsorption on the catalyst can lead to passivation, where the surface saturates with reaction intermediates or products such as solid Li2S2 or Li2S, thus blocking active sites and hindering further LiPSs reduction. CV measurements with a rotating disk electrode (RDE) can confirm passivation by showing a decrease in current over time, indicative of reduced catalytic activity. The forced convection of RDE ensures a continuous supply of LiPSs, minimizing the impact of concentration changes and providing a more accurate measure of intrinsic activity. Doping with various cations can enhance the affinity of ZnS toward LiPSs. Compared with doped samples, the pure ZnS with the weakest binding ability to LiPSs exhibits the lowest current density in the CV curves under RDE measurement (Fig. 10b) [156]. In contrast, the Mn0.125Zn0.875S, which has the strongest LiPSs affinity, shows a high initial CV current, indicating high catalytic activity (Fig. 10c). Nevertheless, in the low potential range, the current declines gradually over CV cycling, indicative of passivation. Notably, reversing the scan to the high potential region (>2.2 V) restores the high current in subsequent cycles, indicating that the decay in current density is attributed to passivation rather than catalyst degradation or detachment. As for the Co0.125Zn0.875S with a moderate affinity, it shows consistently high and stable current over cycles (Fig. 10d), suggesting minimal passivation. Based on these findings, it is clear that weak chemical affinity is unfavorable for LiPSs adsorption and limits the subsequent conversion, whereas excessively strong affinity leads to the passivation of catalysts, restricting catalytic activity. Therefore, achieving a moderate chemical affinity is essential to ensure fast electrode kinetics for rapid adsorption and conversion of LiPSs, which is crucial in the design of efficient separators for LSBs [156]. Impedance spectroscopy is sensitive to surface adsorption [262]. Consequently, in situ impedance spectroscopy can reflect how the migration of soluble LiPSs influences charge and mass transfer dynamics in LSBs. The catalyst with higher binding ability typically exhibits reduced impedance changes as the battery runs, indicating a mitigated shuttle of LiPSs. In the case of Co0.12Ni1.88S2/NiO with high chemical affinity, the electrode shows lower and stable electrolyte impedance in situ EIS measurements due to the elimination of the diffusion of LiPSs [211]. In sharp contrast, the NiS/NiO with weaker affinity exhibits dramatic changes in impedance due to the contamination of LiPSs. As a result, in situ impedance spectroscopy is a useful yet affordable technique to examine the affinity of LiPSs in the assessment of functional separators. 4.2 Spectral technique Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (UV/Vis) can indirectly assess a catalyst's chemical affinity for LiPSs by measuring their concentration in solution, based on the characteristic absorption peaks of LiPSs. By tracking concentration changes of LiPSs before and after adsorption, the catalyst’s affinity can be inferred, as illustrated in Fig. 10e [156]. However, while this method provides a rough estimate of adsorption efficiency, it cannot precisely determine adsorption energies owing to variations in specific surface areas and active sites among catalysts. A catalyst with a larger surface area or higher density of active sites may show greater adsorption efficiency, even if its intrinsic affinity is weaker. Consequently, UV/Vis spectroscopy can rank catalysts based on adsorption performance but does not offer detailed insights into the strength or nature of the adsorption process. More advanced techniques, such as in situ spectroscopy or theoretical calculations, are necessary for a more accurate assessment of the adsorption energies and underlying mechanisms [263]. In situ detection techniques, such as Raman and UV/Vis spectroscopy, are valuable tools for real-time monitoring of LiPSs. As shown in Fig. 10f, g, Raman peaks corresponding to LiPSs species (e.g., Li2S4, Li2S6) reflect their concentration, with higher concentrations indicating weaker affinities of the catalyst [122]. Similarly, in situ UV/Vis spectroscopy tracks LiPSs concentration fluctuations during the SRR by monitoring the absorption peaks that correspond to various LiPSs, providing complementary information on catalyst adsorption behavior (Fig. 10h) [264]. While both techniques offer insights into the relative adsorption strengths of catalysts, they do not provide precise adsorption energies for further mechanism analysis. This limitation arises from experimental factors such as catalyst surface area, structure, and electrochemical environment. Moreover, these methods can identify trends in adsorption but cannot directly quantify the molecular interactions or binding energies of LiPSs with various catalysts. To better understand the adsorption mechanism and accurately investigate catalyst-LiPSs interaction strength, integration with computational methods like DFT is necessary. In addition, XPS, combined with bond order-length-strength (BOLS) theory, provides a detailed understanding of interface electronic energies and enables the quantitative assessment of adhesive properties at heterogeneous interfaces in two-dimensional materials. At the atomic level, material interfaces are influenced by quantum trapping (QT) or charge polarization (CP), both of which alter the core-level potential of atoms. QT occurs when electron localization at the interface increases surface potential, while CP arises from charge misalignment across the interface. Both QT and CP can affect the strength of interactions between the material and LiPSs [265]. To quantify these effects, the ratio ΔE v(I)/ΔE v(B) = γ is used, where ΔE v(I) and ΔE v(B) represent the atomic interface and bulk binding energy shifts of sulfides, respectively [265]. A γ > 1 indicates QT dominance for weaker interactions, while a γ < 1 suggests CP dominance, which enhances interactions. The interfacial adhesive energy (Γ), which governs catalyst binding with LiPSs, is calculated using BOLS theory’s bond energy and length formulas. The greater the atomic cohesive energy (E c), the better the stability of the material (Fig. 10i). For materials such as CS, CuS, FeS2, MoS2, and SnS2, the Γ are 2.33, 3.42, 5.97, 5.60, and 4.69 J m−2, respectively. FeS2 exhibits the strongest binding ability, followed by MoS2, SnS2, and CuS. These results indicate that materials with higher adhesive energies, like FeS2, are more effective in anchoring LiPSs and reducing the shuttle effect [265]. These insights, which are difficult to obtain with conventional techniques, make XPS and BOLS theory powerful tools for identifying highly active electrode materials for LSBs. By elucidating the fundamental mechanisms of catalyst-LiPS interactions, these methods can inform the design of efficient separators with greatly enhanced catalytic activity and improved long-term stability. 4.3 Theoretical calculation DFT calculations and MD simulations provide critical insights into the atomic-level interactions between catalysts and LiPSs in LSBs. These techniques enable precise calculation of binding energies and surface energy, which are essential to understanding how materials adsorb and stabilize LiPSs. The calculation of binding energies of catalysts to LiPSs is viable, as frequently reported in various works. Since I α d (number of dangling bonds) couldn’t be examined from DFT calculations, the surface energy cannot be calculated directly via the expression in Section 2. Fortunately, the total surface energy can be computed from slab models (E slab). In this case, the surface energy is expressed as the following equation [266] γ = E s l a b - NE b u l k 2 S where the NE bulk is the energy of the equivalent bulk atoms. By systematically varying surface terminations, vacancy density, or exposing specific crystal facets, the theoretical method can calculate γ for surfaces with different numbers of unsaturated bonds. Decomposing γ into contributions from individual dangling bonds, the effective Eα for each dangling bond is estimated. By bringing the γ and Eα into the formula in Section 2, we can back-calculate the optimal I α d that balances strong LiPSs adsorption (high activity) and reversible migration (avoiding over-binding). Therefore, DFT and MD simulations offer theoretical values for chemical affinities, guiding the design of electrode materials with improved performance. For example, DFT calculations by Li et al. directly show that CoN4-carbon surfaces offer stronger adsorption energy toward Li2S and Li2S6 than pure carbon or N-doped carbon [267]. Nevertheless, DFT calculations primarily focus on equilibrium states rather than the kinetics or dynamic processes involved in reactions, like the shuttle effect. While DFT can provide important information about reaction mechanisms, transition states, and activation energies, it does not capture real-time dynamics, such as adsorption/desorption rates or reaction kinetics. Methods like MD or kinetic Monte Carlo (KMC) simulations are better for these tasks [268,269]. Additionally, DFT calculations neglect solvent effects, which are crucial for LiPSs’ adsorption in the electrolyte, necessitating simulations that incorporate solvation effects or more complex models closer to the real world. The strengths, limitations, and appropriate applications of the aforementioned techniques for evaluating LSBs are summarized in Table 2 . Although these methods have been extensively explored, accurately quantifying the binding energy to LiPSs remains a significant challenge. The absence of standardized quantitative metrics to depict the optimal chemical affinity (e.g., binding energy thresholds) and the disparities in ideal adsorption energies among various LiPS species (e.g., Li2S4 vs. Li2S6) limit the understanding of the real electrode processes. To advance mechanism understanding, multimodal analytical methodologies, such as in situ Raman spectroscopy coupled with electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (Raman-EIS), should be employed to dynamically probe the adsorption behavior of LiPSs at the catalytic surface. Such approaches permit direct structure-activity relationship analysis by linking adsorption geometries with reaction kinetics. Moreover, the establishment of standardized testing protocols (e.g., defined LiPS solution concentrations, adsorption durations) and the construction of integrated databases combining experimental and computational data will accelerate material screening for efficient separators. Additionally, the combination of electrochemical analysis, spectroscopic evaluation, theoretical modeling, and in situ monitoring is expected to provide a more comprehensive and accurate understanding of catalyst surface chemistry. Therefore, future research should prioritize dynamic interface engineering, high-precision characterization, and standardized evaluation protocols to promote the development of high-performance separators for long-cycle-life and high-energy-density LSBs. 5 Summary and perspectives 5.1 Summary of surface binding affinity and engineering techniques This report provides an in-depth review of recent advances in the rational design of separators for LSBs, focusing on addressing fundamental issues related to surface binding and surface energy within materials science. Optimizing the surface energy and increasing dangling bond states of separators can enhance the adsorption and catalysis of LiPSs, thereby facilitating the SRR and reducing lithium dendrite formation. The following key insights have been derived: • Relationship between chemical affinity and catalytic activity. The moderate chemical affinity of separators is crucial for effectively trapping LiPSs and fast conversion reactions. Weak affinity results in poor bonding ability with LiPSs. Strong affinity may lead to catalyst poisoning, hindering the subsequent conversion reactions. This highlights the need for balanced adsorption strength to prevent the detrimental accumulation of byproducts. • Electrolyte competition for adsorption. Electrolytes (e.g., DOL and DME) can compete for LiPSs adsorption on the separators. The membrane’s affinity for LiPSs must surpass that of the electrolyte to enable selective capture of LiPSs. The over-adsorption of electrolytes may disrupt ion distribution and mass transport. This imbalance increases internal resistance and destabilizes the SEI film, compromising the safety and stability of LSBs. • Instability of high surface energy states. Separators with high surface energy may exhibit increased activity owing to abundant dangling bond states; however, they may also be unstable. Strategies for passivating high-energy sites, such as surface passivation, use of additives, and post-processing techniques, are crucial to balance activity and durability, thereby enhancing long-term performance and preserving catalytic efficiency. • Complexity of structure configuration, The optimal binding affinity for LiPSs is influenced by the configuration of active sites, such as pyrrolic and pyridinic N. Balancing different configurations with different binding ability is essential to prevent excessive trapping of LiPSs while ensuring efficient conversion and preventing the accumulation of solid Li2S2 on the catalyst surface. • Selection of the most stable configuration in DFT calculations. Given these intricate interactions, computational methods, particularly DFT calculations, are essential for accurately predicting and optimizing binding affinities across various configurations. DFT calculations provide insights into how geometric structures and surface energies influence the adsorption and catalytic behavior of LiPSs. However, selecting the most stable computational model is critical, as minor variations in calculation methods can result in significant discrepancies in predicted binding energies. These insights highlight the critical balance between surface energy, surface affinity, and material stability in the design of separators for LSBs. Optimizing these parameters, along with selecting the appropriate active site configurations, is essential for enhancing LiPSs adsorption, accelerating the SRR, and ensuring long-term membrane performance. Future research should focus on fine-tuning these factors to achieve stable, high-performance separators that effectively mediate LiPSs conversion while maintaining material durability. To enhance the performance of separators in lithium-sulfur batteries, various modification strategies have been explored, including size engineering, crystal facet engineering, defect engineering, chemical doping, phase engineering and disordered systems, hybrid structures, and surface functionalization. These strategies aim to optimize the properties of separators, such as surface energy, active site configuration, and structural integrity. The key principles behind these approaches are summarized as follows: • Single-atom catalysts (SACs). SACs enhance the performance of separators in LSBs, offering increased surface energy and more unsaturated coordination sites to improve SRR activity. However, optimizing the binding affinity and stability of SACs remains challenging, particularly in preventing excessive binding to LiPSs and the formation of solid Li2S2. Further theoretical and experimental work is needed to refine the SACs fabrication and enhance their catalytic performance in separators. • High-index facets (HIFs). HIFs can provide a higher density of low-coordinated atoms, thus improving the binding ability to LiPSs. Surface passivation, alloying, and HEA are reported to further balance the stability and catalytic activity of the target facets. These facet-engineered materials show significant potential for improving SRR kinetics and long-term stability in LSBs. • Defective structure. Defective structures can introduce electronic polarization and increase the number of dangling bond states to improve the binding affinity for LiPSs. Defects like vacancies, dislocations, and strained systems create unsaturated sites that enhance interactions with LiPSs, accelerating the SRR. However, excessive defects can cause structural instability and over-binding to LiPSs, compromising performance. Thus, controlling defect concentration is vital to balance catalytic activity and stability. • Chemical doping. Chemical doping in the separators of LSBs plays a crucial role in altering the electronic structure of the host material to regulate the binding ability of LiPSs. Non-metal doping can enhance the chemical affinity to LiPSs through electron redistribution and the creation of active sites, while metal doping adjusts the Fermi level to influence surface charge distribution and improve LiPSs adsorption. Co-doping further synergizes these effects to enhance the overall electrochemical stability and catalytic activity. • Strain engineering. By applying tensile or compressive strain to affect the overlapping of the electronic cloud in the chemical bonds, the d-band center could be modulated to strengthen the interaction with LiPSs for fast SRR. In late transition metals, tensile strain causes band narrowing and an upshift of the d-band center, while early transition metals show the opposite effect. • Crystal phase regulation. Crystal phase regulation can enhance surface reactivity by modulating electronic properties and surface structures, which increases the density of dangling bond states and surface energy. This improvement leads to more active sites for LiPSs binding and conversion, ultimately boosting catalytic activity and facilitating faster Li+ diffusion for fast SRR. • Disordered system. Disordered systems, such as amorphous materials, can increase surface defects, dangling bonds, and broaden d-orbital electron distributions to improve the chemical affinity for LiPSs and enhance catalytic activity. However, the disordered systems are inherently unstable and require stabilization through surface passivation or heterostructure design to maintain long-term performance in the separators of LSBs. • Hybrid materials. Hybrid structures can effectively combine materials with complementary properties, such as high polarity and electrical conductivity. The incorporation of polymers or inorganic materials with a high elastic modulus increases mechanical strength and thermal stability, preventing dendrite growth. Furthermore, introducing interfacial states and built-in electric fields enhances electron transfer and accelerates Li+ transport, resulting in improved electrochemical kinetics. The exquisite combination of hybrid materials presents a promising way to construct efficient separators for LSBs. 5.2 Prospectives The discussions above highlight several critical directions for developing efficient separators in LSBs. One central strategy is optimizing surface energy and the configuration of active sites to enhance both the capture and conversion of LiPSs. High surface energy and abundant dangling bond states can significantly improve LiPS adsorption; however, excessive chemical affinity may lead to undesirable outcomes. For instance, it may hinder the reversible transport of LiPSs to the cathode, effectively turning the separator into a working electrode and eventually causing the failure of the sulfur host or current collector. Moreover, overly strong interactions can trigger electrolyte competition or poisoning effects, compromising catalytic activity and slowing SRR kinetics. Therefore, a balanced design is essential—selecting optimal surface properties to ensure effective LiPS confinement without impeding reversibility. To provide more quantitative guidance for material selection, we have compiled benchmark binding energy values between various representative materials and Li2S4, summarized in Table 3 . These values serve as useful references for evaluating chemical affinity and interfacial characteristics. For consistency, the binding energies were normalized using the most stable Li2S4 configuration. To effectively suppress the shuttle effect, separator materials should exhibit stronger binding affinities toward LiPSs than the electrolyte (e.g., >0.87 eV for DME/DOL solvents) [254]. High-affinity surfaces also help suppress Li dendrites. However, when the separator functions as a “secondary electrode,” the optimal binding energy range becomes more complex. For example, Zhang and coauthors proposed that SRR follows two symmetric and four asymmetric reaction pathways, where the latter-featuring LiS3 • intermediates-are favored at lower binding energies (<∼1.4 eV) [37]. Volcano-type relationships suggest that overly high binding energies (>2 eV) can hinder catalytic turnover [270], yet in some cases (e.g., >1.257 eV), enhanced S–S bond cleavage in solid Li2S2 may still benefit SRR [271]. These competing mechanisms remain poorly understood and merit further investigation. As shown in Table 3 , the most investigated catalyst materials, including SACs, heterostructures, carbon-based materials, TMCs, TMOs, TMNs, MOFs, and alloys, exhibit a wide range of BEs, suggesting considerable room for optimization via surface energy and dangling bond tuning strategies. Despite their promise, high-surface-energy materials face stability challenges. Their enhanced LiPS adsorption arises from features such as excessive vacancies or dopants, which also compromise structural integrity during cycling. Structural reconstruction or aggregation of active sites can degrade Li+ transport and result in capacity fade. Although surface passivation and hybrid material strategies have been proposed to improve stability, these often come at the expense of catalytic activity. Thus, innovative approaches are required to develop separators that simultaneously offer high activity and long-term structural stability. In this context, advanced characterization and computational methods are indispensable for rational design. Techniques such as DFT allow for detailed atomic-level predictions of binding energies and surface interactions. Nonetheless, these calculations often rely on simplified structural models due to computational limitations, which may lead to discrepancies with experimental behavior. Incorporating more accurate models (e.g., those accounting for electrolyte interactions) will be essential in future studies. In parallel, in situ characterization techniques can offer real-time insights into the dynamic behavior of LiPSs and separators during battery operation. The integration of precise simulations with advanced diagnostics will enable better alignment between theory and practical application. Equally important is the scalability of separator production, which remains a bottleneck for commercial deployment. While commercial PP and PE membranes are produced at the industrial scale, most modified separators are still limited to laboratory research. Bridging this gap requires adopting scalable, cost-effective fabrication techniques such as blade coating, slot-die coating, and spray deposition, especially when combined with roll-to-roll processing, in-line thickness control, and surface characterization. Future work should emphasize designs that meet both electrochemical and manufacturing requirements to ensure seamless integration into current battery production lines. These advances are essential to translating high-performance laboratory materials into viable technologies for next-generation LSBs. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) represent a next-generation energy storage technology, but widespread applications are restricted by the shuttle of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). The rational design of separators has been demonstrated to be one of the most efficient and cost-effective strategies to curb the shuttle effect, and tremendous research progress has been achieved. The efficiency of a separator depends on its interaction with LiPSs, which is governed by the surface energy and binding strength. Despite several review works that have been reported to advance the separators, most of them primarily focus on active material innovation and construction. The most crucial issues of surface binding energy have not been systematically reviewed, limiting the precise design of efficient separators. In this review, fundamentals related to surface energy and binding interactions with LiPSs are comprehensively analyzed and discussed. With surface binding and energy main lines, the advancements in separator engineering strategies are elaborately summarized and discussed. Moreover, techniques for evaluating affinity to LiPSs are thoroughly analyzed to avoid any ambiguities in measurement. Based on the research context, valuable research directions are suggested to construct efficient separators. This work provides guidelines to regulate the surface binding and energy of separators for high-performance LSBs.
